title: Case Study: Post-Lobectomy Shoulder and Chest Dysfunction in a Retired Carpenter
clinical_history: Mr. George Allen is a 68-year-old retired carpenter who underwent a right upper lobectomy six weeks ago for early-stage non-small cell lung carcinoma. The surgery was performed via open thoracotomy. Since discharge, George complains of persistent right-sided chest and shoulder pain, reduced shoulder range of motion, and difficulty taking deep breaths or engaging in activities such as washing, dressing, or reaching overhead. He reports muscle weakness, notable fatigue, and an ongoing fear of movement due to pain. He denies fever, acute respiratory distress, or other complications, but expresses concern about slow progress. Pain is worse with coughing, deep inspiration, or arm movement. He uses a hand-held fan for breathlessness, and a prescribed incentive spirometer.

nprs.affected_area: right thoracic wall (intercostals, serratus anterior, latissimus dorsi, pectoralis major/minor), associated with post-surgical pain and muscle guarding
right shoulder girdle (deltoid, trapezius, rotator cuff), related to reduced movement and compensatory overuse

aggrevating_factors: Arm elevation above shoulder height, deep inspiration, coughing, prolonged sitting unsupported, lying on the right side.
picture: [image would highlight right anterior and lateral thorax, right shoulder and scapular region]
easing_factors: Supporting right arm with a pillow, shallow breathing, gentle range of motion exercises, resting in a semi-reclined position, applying warm compresses.
past_history: History of hypertension (well-controlled), osteoarthritis of left knee. No prior pulmonary disease. Retired 3 years ago, previously physically active.
medical_history: Recent right upper lobectomy for lung carcinoma, hypertension, osteoarthritis.
medications: Paracetamol 1g TID, codeine 15mg PRN for severe pain, amlodipine 5mg OD.
personal_history: Lives with wife, enjoys woodworking and gardening (currently limited). Ex-smoker, quit 10 years ago after 40 pack-years. No alcohol use. Reports mild anxiety post-surgery about long-term prognosis and loss of independence.
imaging: Post-operative chest X-ray shows expected changes post-lobectomy; no acute complications.
